comment_0:
I think that all songs will mean something different to all..you know "Eye Of the Beholder" type shit.
This song talks to me about my mental ilneess of being bipolar.
I feel alot of the rage and being misunderstood as crazy when in fact I am not. The word mental illness gives people a certain image that is just not fuckin'true.There are different degrees of everything.
Being "Labeled mentally deranged" but by who?
I have read alot of these lyrics from day one and with the most recent St Anger song "Unnamed Feeling" get the impression that James might be BP also.It lad me to drug abuse to change my moods I didn't like and try and keep people away.
One problem with BPdisorder is that you "cycle" these feelings and moods can't be controlled.There is no cure.  
So i tcan seem that time stands still at times and no one leaves, it's always there.
I know this isn't a very fuckin' metal explination but believe me I am VERY metal.This is just a song that gives a point of view from someone that has been called mentally ill and is being forced to see that his views on things are wrong.Finally the only way to feel like you can make a point is to kill the fucks that have been holding you down and telling you that you are getting better.
Trust me this disease isn't fun and and the funny thing is the docs  tell me that this music is too negative. Like "Fade To Black".. I say bullshit. I feel good knowing that there is someone else that feels alot like I do and has the balls and talent to sing about it. Want more BP lyricss? Read "Until It Sleeps" and alot of others and as mentioned "Unnamed Feeling". Everyone feels like this jsut some of us have a harder time controling it.

Now the funny side of this song is I used to listen to it on my way to work at the factory and it fuckin' fits perfectly there for me too!
By the way.."Master Of Puppets" is THE best thrash metal LP EVER. Bar none. From  "Battery" to the last kickyour ass tune "Damage, Inc" it just doesn't get ANY better!
comment_1: Uh dude, what the hell are you talking about? A man drowns himself, a man slits his throat, someone cuts his nuts off and bleeds to death, they smoke pot, visit prostitues, and someone gets a lobotomy, causing him to have a fate worse than death. Then, the Indian kills him because he knows he wouldn't want to live that way. The Metallica song doesn't do the book justice, and if you haven't read it, go pick it up immedietally, it's a great read.
comment_2: i think its about people being thought to be crazy when they're not and its the way that the "inmates" are treated
comment_3:
It is about someone who is in a sanitarium. A sanitarium is a mental institution which can be left on a inmate's own will. 

"No locked doors - No windows barred" 
"No things to make my brain seem scared" 


On the other hand the 'sanitarium' could also be a simile for the society.
comment_4:
I feel it calls our entire existence the sanitarium. How the general population is controlled and exploited by the government. How those who rebel are made to seem crazy.

People do not use logic and reason but preconceptions and peer pressure to determine such a thing and it helps them keep us in a bubble.

But the song refuses to give in, with frustration trying to rally the people to wake up and take charge.
comment_5: In my opinion, the Ten Commandments was a soft movie, and one I wouldn;t have thought  would make people scream "Die! Die!" as loud as they could, but it happened. Based on the book or movie, I could care less, this song just fucking rocks.
comment_6: Partly based on a movie called, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", it's about breaking down and being kept in a sanitarium.
comment_7: I belive this about how parents, including mine, had a preconcieved image of what Metallica was.  I belive this song points out that they don't like it.

comment_12:
It is about someone who is in a sanitarium. A sanitarium is a mental institution which can be left on a inmate's own will. 

that 'retarded' movie of yours... is about a sanitarium, but one guy is locked up in there

"listen damnit we will win"  is NOT about leaving the place whenever you want to!
comment_13:
One of the greatest songs ever written about other people's misconceived notions of who YOU are.  This song is an anthem to anybody who has ever wrongly been accused of something.

  Metallica has composed their masterpiece with "Sanitarium".  The lyrics can be applied to many different circumstances in life, yet the underlying meaning of the song is quite clear.  Far and away the best Metallica song ever, and worth the price of the "Master Of Puppets" cd alone.
comment_14: One Flew Over the Cuckoos nest seems a bit too soft of a movie for a Metallica song, doesnt it?.. It would make more sense if the song was about the book, which instead takes the point of view of the indian who only pretends to be deaf and dumb. He does this because he doesn't want to conform with the rest of the institute or anyone else. Makes sense.
comment_15: I'm surprised so few people posted about this song. Anyway, bottom line is that this is one of the most quintessential Metallica songs of all time, and every single solo in it fits the mood of the song as best as it seemingly could. The dynamics of the playing also come out very well. One of my favorite songs of all time, without a doubt.
comment_16: Another thing to keep in mind is that, around when this song was written, many of the corrupt mental hospitals (Danvers, in particular), were being shut down, as more and more of the cruel treatments became public. Along with things like hydrotherapy and electroshock, many of the pschiatrists at these hospitals literally gave patients multiple personalities or D.I.D. by making the patients think they had these disorders, which do not naturally occur.
comment_17:
This is a great song. I really do think it is about a crazy person, not one wrongly accused of being crazy. "....your dream is my reality....". 
To me, that means that in a normal person's dream, their's can be as weird as it is. But the crazy person's real life is that weird. He/she imagines all that strange stuff and thinks it's real.
comment_18:
My point of view : the song is a confession from a man who lives in a society where he's misunderstood and where if he tries to think against society's will  he becomes a sort of an outcast. They try to send him 'straight' boycotting him blaming him for things that aren't true labeling him 'mentally deranged' . He takes refuge in his own world of dreams 
 'Sleep my friend and you will see
  That dream is my reality'
he wishes the world would be a better place to be.
in his mind he creates a revolution, which is bound to fail . It's a cry for help ,unheard by anyone.
  Also bears some resemblance to 'The Unforgiven'.
comment_19:
I think the song is a metaphor for being insane..
"Dream the same thing every night, 
I see our freedom in my sight"  I dont see it as being locked up and trying to get out, more as being on the recovery.
So.. maybe the sanitarium itself plays a part, but what really is his "cage" is his own mind.
comment_20:
"Fear of living on 
natives getting restless now 
Mutiny in the air 
got some death to do 
Mirror stares back hard 
Kill, it's such a friendly word 
seems the only way 
for reaching out again"

seems "he" preferred his crazy-thoughts :P
comment_21:
I think some people are interpreting this song a little too figuratively when it should be read more literaly.  People with mental "issues" are getting more and more agitated by the conditions in their institution and are on the edge of revolt.  A nice angry theme perfect for a song of this caliber and great lyrics to complement this very excellent song.

Of course there are some symbolic parallels you can draw about being repressed by society and all, but the case for symbolism isn't as obvious as in the title track Master of Puppets.

comment_31: I like how you guys are actually talking about the meaning behind this song and not complaining about some insignificant thing that everyone does.  NEWAYS ON TO MY THOUGHTS.  I think this song covers some of the same topics as The Unforgiven.  It's somewhat about society locking us in our cage to be like everyone else i.e. make us mentally well. The thing about no locked doors or bared windows is interesting.  That probably means that it is like a sanitarium where they dont lock us in and we can leave, but ppl are too afraid that they will stand out and look stupid.  Sry if you think im over-analyzing the song.  Good song though, i listen to a radio station in Indianapolis that has something called "Mandatory Metallica" where they play three songs by Metallica every night.  They've been doing it for YEARS and the play their older stuff more than they play their newer stuff.  Big plus.
comment_32: yeah that is a kinda accurate understanding of the song...i think the song is mainly about society as osmeone earlier said...but the way the bureaucrats attempt to pacify the public the way they see fit, which does not sit well with everyone...don't get me wrong, I am not an anti-establishment crusader, on the contrary, I am completely white-colar, but from a nonconfromists point of view, this song cries out the fact that people in society need different attentions, and that the current (in the 80s) system does not aggree with the narrator's idea.

comment_44: This song can go both ways. It can be talking about being mentally ill, and litterally being locked in a Sanitarium, or being caged by society. To me, it speaks to me about my expirence in a mental health institution. It was scary as hell. You have NO control, unless you go there voluntarily, and if you would do that, then you really are crazy. You have people who tell you when to wake up, and when you refuse to put up with their bullshit, they put you on another damned drug. You cant go home. Its...one of the most depressing, horrifying things one could ever experience.

comment_46:
ppl...

"James Hetfield: The idea for that song came from the movie "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest". "Fade to Black" worked well, and we wanted to have another slow, clean picking type of song, this time with a chorus. I had trouble singing that chorus. It's really high, and when I went singing it in the studio, I remember Flemming [Rassmussen] looking at me like, "You're kidding." I said "Shit, I don't know if I can do this!" So I ended up singing it lower than I intended, but we put a higher harmony on it and it worked pretty well. The riff for that song was lifted from some other band, who shall remain anonymous. (GuitarWorld issue of '91) "

check out :
encycmet.com/songs/…

comment_56:
Ok people hereâs how it works, the brainwashing flows in this order, government, religious(fanatics), white color(with something to lose), parents, then to the children and the ânativesâ(subclass). This song might be âbasedâ on that movie, but it involves much more. It compares the brainwashing techniques(and believe me they exist) of  society to that of a mental hospital. There is a cage that people build for themselves so they can be ânormalâ where âno one leaves and no one will.â But in his dreams he is free, and those dreams have become his reality. So he invites us to sleep, to close our eyes to what weâre told to be, told to see, and made to believe, and thus recreate society.
	âBuild my fear of what's out there and cannot breathe the open airâ could refer to the government scaring the people about whatâs out there (weapons of mass destruction) but doesnât want us really see for our self. Or how we build our childrenâs fear of the ârealâ world without letting them see for themselves, unable to love, trust, or truly feel. Sanitarium is a man made often self made cage. A revolt from the norm is the war cry. âThey see it right, they see it wellâ If left to our own we are surely âcrazyâ but mass control is saving no one, on the contrary it has enslaved us all. âNo more can they keep us in Listen, damn it, we will winâ

comment_72:
for a start i love this song. i think it is awesome obviously one of their best. I always have it with me on my ipod or my phone.

lines like
"No locked doors, No windows barred
No things to make my brain seem scarred"
"Whisper things into my brain
assuring me that I'm insane"

he's getting better, can't you tell?"

that is exactly what happens in an asylum trust me i have first hand experience.
comment_73:
its really plain to see they are talking about someone in an asylum 

if you have ever been to a mental hospital for 6 months and had nothing wrong with you and your parents just leave you there and talk to the doctors about you while hiding everything from you and just keeping you locked up while you just want to be left alone you want out of there more than anything it drives you insane.. the song is right on the money as far as cannot breathe the open air and dreaming about freedom and everything they say its hell in those places pure hell 
the only thing you can think about is going home or escaping but they tell you that you are unstable they dont even care you just want them to leave you alone and eventually you will explode on them JUST LEAVE ME ALONE!!!
comment_74: This song is even more relevent in modern times, where many thousands more are being drugged EVERY YEAR, and countless others committed, no small proportion because of drug side effects and withdrawal. Even then, that doesn't excuse violating peoples' basic human rights to 'treat them', especially in an inhuman environment.

comment_80: First off, for all of those of you who don't believe so, this son WAS inspired by "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" because I read an interview with Kirk and James in Guitar World Magazine that said so. Secondly, I think this song is just about someone who is locked up in a Sanitarium and wants to break free but can't. The part that says "No locked doors, no windows barred, no things to make my brain seem scarred..." means that he's locked up in the Sanitarium, but they make it seem like they are not prisoners there by not having locks on the doors, or barred-windows, they just don't let them leave. They do this sometimes for mental patients and it makes them seem like nothing is wrong with them, so they don't feel like imprisoned or insecure

I think this song is about people who dream "the dream is my reality" but people keep them locked up or keep them from going after there dreams 'They keep me locked up in this cage" and they don't like being locked up. They just want to go off and see if they can get there dream.

comment_89: I believe the song is about someone who has gone insane by his own life.  He believes that we are all crippled by the limits of reality.  He realizes what an outcast he is in society and takes notice of how everyone calls him crazy.  But to him, they're the insane.  Eventually, he is drawn to homicidal thoughts, believing that he is doing the world right by "freeing" the others of their limits of the real world, thus preparing to kill by the end of the song.
comment_90: when i heard the song i thought it was being in an insane asylum and everyone rising up to escape
comment_91: It's about how being locked in a mental asylum can make the insane go even more insane.
comment_94: I conceive the lyrics slightly on James' issues with his relationships with his family, His father didn't really care and his mother died of cancer (he blamed Christianity for his mom's faith, see god that failed for more.) His parents were extremely religious and did not approve of "Rock music" and when James started his band, they freaked and then later his issues with his mother poured onto his plate and encouraged his alcoholism. The supposed "Insanity" he preaches throughout the song seems to be about the effects of Alcoholism: Short fuse, Apathy, and mood swings..so on so forth  ( First verse the frozen image you get explains the apathy part and the mood swings in the choruses.) And The Second verse explains the therapy sessions he takes and the restrictions of activities and sessions that seem to last forever to him frustrate him to no end and he thinks they don't know what they're doing and they don't get him. Then in the pre-chorus leading to the  second chorus explains that they start to get it but they don't know how to really fix it. And the final verse: about the natives are his friends and possibly the media, pressuring him and the mirror part seems to be about looking at himself and hating himself for what he is but he still denies that he has an issue and just has an urge to kill everything around him and getting away from it all (most of this information is from the metallica histories on their site and Wikipedia.)

This describes what the government does to you and how they control you with fear and propaganda. Thing is they make people like me who understand them out to be crazy ,all because we are the real threat to them just like the always have.

comment_96: This song is a ballad told in the eyes of someone in an insane asylum, or sanitorium, hence the name "sanitarium". About a man who plans on taking over and breaking out "Mutiny in the air". btw Awesome solo, awesome song altogether
comment_97:
The song is about a sane person who becomes locked in an insane asylum, and is made insane overtime by the doctors who constantly re-enforce the message that he is insane.The treatment backfires when protagonist loses his sanity and is convinced he must kill everyone.

A lot of people have mentioned the film One flew over the cuckoos nest, a film i have not seen. However i'd like to mention the possible connections to Stanley Kubricks A Clockwork Orange and Peter Weirs The Truman Show. Both this song and the films are about a protagonist whose mental illness is produced by the failure of the societies that imprison them, ultimately result the protagonists to defy their rules of their society through drastic measures such as murder,suicide or escape.

As with metallica63, this song struck a personal chord with me. As a young child, my parents became concerned about the slow pace of my development, in contrast to my siblings. The doctors, teachers, and occupational therapists they spoke to said that i was intellectually disabled, and advised that i be sent to
a school where i would be placed in a support class.Everyday my class followed a  routine that involved doing mainly kindergarten things  such as dancing to kids songs and watching preschooler shows. However it hit the fan about two years later in 1999, when i realized that the routine given to the whole class was not going to change and each year we would only be taught at kindergarten levels. Soon I realised my older brother,who was at a different school, was actually learning more advanced things .As the repetition of the aforementioned routines became more apparent i gradually changed from being a happy sociable person, to a frequently upset hypochondriac who would sometimes behave violently if things didn't go my way. Eventually it climaxed when my parents realized that the advice the sought out was incorrect and I was transferred to my brothers school, without an apology or an explanation from my folks and consequently I did not know this until many years later. 

When i did find out, it was in an especially painful period of my life where i was trying to cope with the fact that the relationship between me and one of my few and closest friends was broken. My friend said that the reasoning that i was overly obsessed with video games at the time. At this time, I pretty much had zero support and i did not say anything to my parents about what i was going through. During this period though, my parents at one point had to clean out their cupboards and i stumbled upon a folder containing my medical records which included several letters from the doctors who provided my diagnosis. These letters mentioned that i had displayed symptoms of autism such as obsessionality which i immediately linked to my alledged obsession with video games. The impact of these letters left me devestated. Within a handful of minutes I had been told the following things

a. Why i spent several years in a dreadful school environment
b. That i was born with an intellectual disability that my parents never told me about.

and due to a lack of understanding at the time, i had the impression that
c. My friend had left me because an external factor was interfering with the functionality of my brain and was stopping me from being myself. 

Point C was particularly important to me as i spent several years wishing i had known about the diagnosis earlier so my friend would understand my obsessionality. Consequently i lived in denial about my hobbies believing they were the result of the autism and not me being me. 

Eventually in recent years, i began bringing up my past in several conversations to my parents who explained that the doctors had mis-diagnosed me as being intellectually disabled and are trying re-enforce the message that im doing well in school. I doubt that though as I'm now considering leaving school, because i wish to avoid a repeat of the emotional traumas I've experienced. My friend came back into contact with me and confessed that he was a jerk at the time. We're now best friends. 

If any one of you have managed to read this far into my post, you're probably wondering what the point of it is. I'll say it now. The point I wish to make is that judging from my personal experiences, the song Welcome Home (Santarium) performed by James Hetfield, Kirk Hammett, Lars Ulrich and of course the late and sorely missed Cliff Burton, provides the warning that a mis-diagnosis and the related treatments can have a serious effect on the lives of patients especially in regards to their sense of self. The effects can be serious enough to nearly break ones sense of identity, causing their behavior to go hay wire, before they spend the rest of their lives dealing in its aftermath.
comment_98: I was in a mental hospital few months ago and this song keep playing in my head. All the words make perfect sense
comment_99: I think lines like "dream the same dream every night" and "fear of living on" suggest the person is a guy in an asylum with some kind Of disorder. It also seems to deal with how he is treated as a patient.
comment_100: Well, I relate to this song, too. growing up with a family member that is close to you that is like 98% gifted and being the idiot of the family (Having my father thourougly convinced Im Mentally ill, hell flip out on me for no reason and shout "YOU HAVE A MENTAL PROBLEM!" or "YOURE A HEADCASE!" and thats where the "Sanitarium, Leave me be...." part ties in for me)And the second verse describes how i'm determined to show the world that I am worth something too, (The  "Listen,Damnit, We will win" Part)and the last part, the "mirror stares back Hard....." Suits how in the end i always think: "Who am I kidding? I'll never be good enough" The thoughts of giving up. It is an excellent song. I love it.

A little further in depth though, I think this is about someones normalcy to themselves but labeled and judged differently by others. The rage of being told that their mentally deranged when they themselves dont feel different at all is stifling.
comment_102: I've always thought this song to be about a person who is wrongly held in a mental asylum and tries to convince others that he's not mental, and trying to get away, but then he just seems more crazier to them... But I'm most likely wrong. Everyone has their own interpretation!
comment_103: I believe this song is about a man with some sort of incurable illness who seeks help in a sanitarium. He was thrown out of society for acting in such a strange manner. In the beginning he enjoys his stay. He can do almost anything he wants there. The longer he stays at the place, the worse his illness gets. He wants to leave but he has become so unconsciously dependent on this place he doesn't. He later goes insane and thinks that the people there are mistreating him. He becomes so crazy he decides the only way to truly leave he must kill himself.
comment_104: The people that have unjustly targeted people as unforgiven and bully them making them believe they are mentally ill trying to submit them into suicide will never win cause you can't hold a good person down.
comment_106:
well this song is basicaly the more badass, master of puppets version of ride the lightning.
its very to the point.
it is about a guy who is mentally ill and is put in a sanitarium. but he hates it there. he thinks its a prison with no bars.
"no locked doors no windows barred, no things to make my brain seem scarred"
he is commenting on how its a wolf in sheeps clothing. it looks nice but it is just like prison.
he continues to say how he wants out.
"i dream my freedom every night"
but his dream came true in the worst form possible. its the sanitarium he resides in.
also, the whole time he is talking to someone. hes telling this "freind" to just let it show him the horror of the sanitarium. so he tells him to leave him alone and get some sleep.
he comes back tomorrow and the man tells us more.
"build fear of whats out there, cannot breathe the open air."
this is about how the sanitarium treats the victims. it crushes their hopes with fear of the world and how it will be worse.
"whisper things into my brain, assuring me that im insane"
more on how the sanitarium treats the victims
"They think our heads are in their hands but violent use brings violent plans"
the man talks on how the torture and pain of the sanitarium fills him with plans of leaving and escaping.
" keep him tied it makes him well, hes getting better cant you tell?"
this is a tidbit not from the man, but from the nurses.
this is how the nurses talk to one another about the paitents.( i will explain later)
"No more can they keep us in listen, damn it, we will win"
this is the man on his plans of escape. and how he will bring others to safety. away from the sanitarium.
"they see right, they see well, they think it saves us from our hell"
more on how oblivious the nurses are to the pain
"Fear of living on
Natives getting restless now
Mutiny in the air
Got some death to do
Mirror stares back hard
Kill, itâs such a friendly word
Seems the only way
For reaching out again"
and this is the saddest part. this section details his escape and how he out of fear murders someone.
and thats what this song is about. how sanitariums dont ever help. they are worse than prison. they torture the victims and they rarely know better than to stop them because of their condition. and the sad part is this isnt really getting better.
and im sure it wont for a while.
please avoid putting your loved ones in homes. they suck.
my mother is a licensed psychologist and she hates sanitariums and homes.
everything from the nurses to the enviornment is absolute shit.
and thats what this song"s story is.

I park my 2*4 and step out, home at last but Iâm in a FRANTC state thinking about my narrow ESCAPE. As my nerves began to calm I remember what MAMA SAID about salvation forgiveness trusting in God and THE FOUR HORSEMEN but I will not pray to THE GOD THAT FAILED seeing as he let my loved one die she truly was MY FRIEND OF MISERY so I decide to live the rest of my life with NO REMORSE.

Knowing my fate as I step into the bathroom that bottle of CYANIDE seems appealing but I will not give up I will FIGHT FIRE WITH FIRE. A brilliant mind I donât deserve to be here but what i did deserves to be punished and that is SAD BUT TRUE. At this rate I donât think even a priest can PURIFY my soul. I think of to myself POOR TWISTED ME but I decide to not have self pity because when it comes to who killed those men I will always be the ONE. From a motherâs boy RONNIE went on to become a killer and sometimes I would think SO WHAT right until the judge decided i would RIDE the LIGHTENING. I know I am SOME KIND of MONSTER but do I really deserve to die. The judge is not letting me off easy as he proclaims THAT WAS JUST YOUR LIFE and now youâve reached THE END OF THE LINE. After a nights sleep I think maybe its fine after all TO LIVE IS TO DIE what is this THE UNNAMED FEELING maybe its time to TURN THE PAGE.
